questions.stem: Simon's concept of 'bounded rationality' proposes that organizational decision-makers:

options.text: Always make perfectly rational decisions that maximize utility
Have limited cognitive capacity, time, and information, leading them to 'satisfice' rather than optimize
Make decisions based entirely on emotions without any rational component
Defer all decisions to computer algorithms

questions.explanation: Herbert Simon (1957) challenged the classical economic model of perfect rationality. Bounded rationality recognizes that decision-makers have limited cognitive processing capacity, incomplete information, and time constraints. Rather than searching for the optimal solution (maximizing), they 'satisfice'—searching until they find a solution that meets a minimum acceptable threshold. Simon received the Nobel Prize in Economics for this work. Bounded rationality is foundational to organizational decision-making theory and contrasts with the rational-economic model of decision-making.

questions.stem: Janis's concept of 'groupthink' describes a pattern of defective decision-making that is most likely to occur when:

options.text: Group members are diverse in background and openly disagree
The group is highly cohesive, insulated from outside opinions, and has a directive leader
The group uses systematic decision-making procedures
Group members work independently and then combine their judgments

questions.explanation: Janis (1972) identified groupthink as a mode of thinking in highly cohesive groups where the desire for unanimity overrides realistic appraisal of alternatives. Antecedent conditions include: high cohesiveness, insulation from external experts, lack of methodical search procedures, directive leadership, and high stress. Symptoms include illusion of invulnerability, collective rationalization, belief in group's inherent morality, stereotyping outgroups, self-censorship, illusion of unanimity, pressure on dissenters, and self-appointed mindguards. The Bay of Pigs invasion is Janis's classic example.

questions.stem: The 'garbage can model' of organizational decision-making (Cohen, March, & Olsen) proposes that decisions result from:

options.text: Systematic analysis of alternatives followed by optimal choice
The random convergence of problems, solutions, participants, and choice opportunities
Hierarchical delegation from top management to lower levels
Democratic voting by all organizational members

questions.explanation: The garbage can model (Cohen, March, & Olsen, 1972) describes decision-making in 'organized anarchies'—organizations with ambiguous goals, unclear technology, and fluid participation. Decisions result from the temporal coincidence of four independent streams: problems (concerns requiring attention), solutions (answers looking for questions), participants (who happens to be involved), and choice opportunities (occasions for decisions). Solutions may be attached to problems they weren't designed to address, and participation varies unpredictably. This model captures the messy reality of decision-making in complex organizations.

questions.stem: According to prospect theory (Kahneman & Tversky), people making decisions under uncertainty tend to be:

options.text: Consistently risk-seeking in all situations
Risk-averse when facing potential gains and risk-seeking when facing potential losses
Perfectly rational regardless of framing
Risk-averse in all situations regardless of framing

questions.explanation: Kahneman and Tversky's (1979) prospect theory demonstrates that people evaluate outcomes relative to a reference point and treat gains and losses asymmetrically. The value function is concave for gains (risk-averse: preferring a sure $500 over a 50% chance of $1,000) and convex for losses (risk-seeking: preferring a 50% chance of losing $1,000 over a sure loss of $500). Additionally, losses loom larger than equivalent gains (loss aversion—losing $100 feels worse than gaining $100 feels good). Framing the same outcome as a gain or loss systematically shifts decisions, violating the rationality assumption.

questions.stem: The Vroom-Yetton-Jago normative decision model helps leaders decide:

options.text: How to motivate employees using expectancy theory
The appropriate level of subordinate participation in decision-making based on situational factors
How to structure organizational hierarchy
Which candidates to select for employment

questions.explanation: The Vroom-Yetton-Jago (VYJ) normative decision model prescribes the appropriate level of subordinate participation in decisions based on situational factors. The model uses a decision tree with diagnostic questions about: quality requirements, leader's information, problem structure, subordinate acceptance, and goal alignment. Decision styles range from autocratic (AI: leader decides alone) through consultative (CI, CII) to group-based (GII: consensus). The model is normative (prescribing what leaders should do) rather than descriptive (what leaders actually do). Research generally supports that decisions matching the model's prescriptions are more effective.

questions.stem: Which of the following are symptoms of groupthink as identified by Janis? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Illusion of invulnerability—excessive optimism and risk-taking
Self-censorship—members withhold dissenting opinions
Encouraging devil's advocate roles
Pressure on dissenters—members who disagree are pressured to conform
Illusion of unanimity—silence is interpreted as agreement

questions.explanation: Janis identified eight symptoms of groupthink, including: illusion of invulnerability (A), self-censorship (B), direct pressure on dissenters (D), and illusion of unanimity (E). Other symptoms include collective rationalization, belief in inherent morality, stereotyping of outgroups, and self-appointed mindguards who protect the group from dissenting information. Encouraging devil's advocate roles (C) is actually a recommended preventive measure against groupthink, not a symptom. Janis recommended: assigning devil's advocates, inviting outside experts, encouraging critical evaluation, and having the leader withhold preferences initially.

questions.stem: Research on cognitive biases in organizational decision-making has identified which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Anchoring bias—over-reliance on the first piece of information encountered
Confirmation bias—seeking information that confirms pre-existing beliefs
Escalation of commitment—increasing investment in a failing course of action
Hindsight bias—believing an outcome was predictable after it occurred
Perfect calibration—decision-makers accurately assess the probability of their judgments being correct

questions.explanation: Well-documented cognitive biases include: Anchoring (Tversky & Kahneman)—initial values disproportionately influence subsequent judgments. Confirmation bias—selectively seeking, interpreting, and remembering information that confirms existing beliefs. Escalation of commitment (Staw)—continuing to invest in failing projects due to sunk cost fallacy, self-justification, and project completion effects. Hindsight bias—believing past events were predictable ('I knew it all along'). Perfect calibration (E) is the opposite of what research shows—people are generally overconfident in their judgments (overconfidence bias).

questions.stem: Techniques designed to improve group decision-making include which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Nominal Group Technique (NGT)—structured idea generation and voting
Delphi method—iterative anonymous expert judgment
Devil's advocacy—assigning a member to critique the group's preferred alternative
Allowing the highest-status member to speak first and set the direction
Dialectical inquiry—deliberately generating opposing positions

questions.explanation: Effective group decision techniques: NGT structures the process—members independently generate ideas, share them round-robin, discuss, then vote privately, reducing conformity pressure. Delphi method uses anonymous iterative rounds of expert judgment with feedback, avoiding groupthink. Devil's advocacy assigns someone to critique the preferred alternative, surfacing weaknesses. Dialectical inquiry generates two opposing positions, forcing the group to synthesize them. Having high-status members speak first (D) actually worsens decisions by anchoring the group and inhibiting dissent—the opposite of best practice.

questions.stem: The phenomenon of 'escalation of commitment' (Staw) is influenced by which psychological mechanisms? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Self-justification—need to appear consistent and validate prior decisions
Sunk cost effect—considering irrecoverable past investments in current decisions
Prospect theory framing—treating continued investment as avoiding a sure loss
Social pressure—public commitment makes it harder to change course
Rational analysis of future expected value

questions.explanation: Escalation of commitment is driven by: self-justification—decision-makers need to justify prior choices, especially when personally responsible (A); sunk cost effect—irrationally considering past investments that cannot be recovered (B); prospect theory framing—treating abandonment as a sure loss, triggering risk-seeking behavior to avoid it (C); and social/normative pressures—public commitment and organizational momentum make reversal difficult (D). Rational analysis of future expected value (E) would actually argue for cutting losses when future prospects are negative—escalation occurs precisely because these biases override rational analysis.

questions.stem: According to research comparing individual versus group decision-making, which statements are accurate? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Groups generally produce higher-quality decisions than the average individual member
Group polarization can lead groups to make more extreme decisions than individuals
Process losses (coordination, motivation) can reduce group decision quality below the best member's level
Groups always outperform their best individual member
Social loafing can reduce individual effort in group decision-making contexts

questions.explanation: Research on individual vs. group decisions: Groups typically outperform the average member (A) due to pooled knowledge and error-checking. Group polarization (Stoner; Myers & Lamm) causes groups to adopt more extreme positions than individual members' average (B). Process losses—production blocking, conformity pressure, coordination difficulties—can reduce quality below the best member (C). Social loafing (Latane et al.) reduces individual effort when responsibility is diffused (E). Groups do NOT always outperform their best member (D)—this depends on task type, group composition, and whether the best member's contribution is recognized and utilized.

questions.stem: Match each decision-making model to its core assumption about how decisions are made:

columns.text: Decision-makers optimize by evaluating all alternatives against clear criteria
Decision-makers satisfice due to cognitive limitations and incomplete information
Decisions result from random intersection of problems, solutions, and participants
Experienced decision-makers use pattern recognition and mental simulation in real-world settings

questions.explanation: The rational-economic model assumes perfect information processing and optimization. Simon's bounded rationality recognizes cognitive limits leading to satisficing. The garbage can model (Cohen, March, Olsen) describes decisions as emerging from the coincidental convergence of independent streams in ambiguous organizations. Klein's Naturalistic Decision Making (NDM) studies how experienced practitioners actually make decisions in complex, time-pressured environments using recognition-primed decision-making (pattern matching from experience and mental simulation).

questions.stem: Match each cognitive bias/heuristic to its primary manifestation:

columns.text: Judging probability based on how easily examples come to mind
Judging probability based on similarity to a prototype, ignoring base rates
Insufficiently adjusting estimates from an initial starting value
Systematically overestimating the accuracy of one's judgments

questions.explanation: Kahneman and Tversky's heuristics and biases program: Availability heuristic—estimating frequency/probability by how easily instances are recalled (vivid or recent events seem more likely). Representativeness—judging probability by similarity to a mental prototype (base rate neglect, conjunction fallacy). Anchoring and adjustment—starting from an initial value and insufficiently adjusting (even random anchors influence judgment). Overconfidence—confidence intervals are too narrow; people believe they're more accurate than they are. These systematic biases affect organizational decision-making at all levels.

questions.stem: For each decision-making context, select ALL techniques that are most appropriate:

rows.text: When conformity pressure and groupthink are major concerns
When a quick decision is needed with available information

questions.explanation: For conformity/groupthink concerns: NGT (independent idea generation before discussion), devil's advocacy (systematic critique), and anonymous brainstorming all reduce social pressure. For geographically dispersed experts: Delphi method is specifically designed for anonymous, iterative expert judgment without face-to-face interaction. For quick decisions: Recognition-primed decision-making (Klein) leverages experienced practitioners' pattern recognition and mental simulation—appropriate when time pressure prevents systematic analysis and the decision-maker has relevant expertise.

questions.stem: For each Vroom-Yetton-Jago decision style, select ALL situational factors that would support using it:

rows.text: Autocratic (AI): Leader decides alone using available information
Consultative (CII): Leader consults group, then decides

columns.text: Decision quality is important and leader lacks sufficient information
Subordinate acceptance is critical for implementation
Leader has all necessary information and acceptance is not crucial

questions.explanation: Autocratic style (AI) is appropriate when the leader has sufficient information, acceptance is not critical, and time is limited—efficiency is maximized without sacrificing quality. Consultative (CII) is appropriate when the leader needs information from the group to improve decision quality—consultation adds information while the leader retains decision authority. Group consensus (GII) is appropriate when subordinate acceptance is essential for implementation and subordinates share organizational goals—participation builds commitment and leverages group knowledge. The VYJ model prescribes different styles based on these situational factors.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about groupthink:

Groupthink (Janis, 1972) occurs in [BLANK1] groups where the desire for consensus overrides [BLANK2] of alternatives. Key antecedent conditions include high cohesiveness, insulation from experts, and [BLANK3] leadership. One symptom is the 'illusion of [BLANK4],' where group members are excessively optimistic and take extreme risks. Janis recommended several preventive measures, including assigning [BLANK5] roles to systematically critique the group's preferred course of action.
questions.explanation: Groupthink occurs in highly cohesive groups where consensus-seeking overrides realistic evaluation. Directive leadership (leader states preferences early) inhibits dissent. The illusion of invulnerability creates excessive optimism. Devil's advocate roles force systematic critique of preferred options. Other preventive measures include: seeking outside expert input, encouraging expression of doubts, holding 'second-chance' meetings, dividing into subgroups, and having the leader withhold preferences until after discussion.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about decision-making biases:

The [BLANK1] heuristic leads decision-makers to estimate probabilities based on how easily instances come to mind, which can be distorted by recency and vividness. The [BLANK2] heuristic causes people to judge probabilities based on similarity to a mental prototype while ignoring base rates. [BLANK3] occurs when decision-makers continue investing in a failing course of action due to sunk costs and self-justification. [BLANK4] describes the tendency for group discussion to amplify individual members' initial leanings, making the group's decision more extreme. These biases can be mitigated through [BLANK5] decision-making procedures and awareness training.
questions.explanation: The availability heuristic uses ease of recall as a proxy for probability—vivid or recent events seem more likely. The representativeness heuristic judges by similarity, leading to base rate neglect and the conjunction fallacy. Escalation of commitment (Staw) drives continued investment in losing projects through sunk cost reasoning and self-justification. Group polarization (initially called 'risky shift') describes how group discussion amplifies pre-existing tendencies. Structured decision procedures (decision matrices, systematic evaluation criteria, accountability) help counteract these biases by imposing discipline on the decision process.

questions.stem: A startup's founding team has worked closely together for three years and has a track record of success. They are now deciding whether to enter a highly competitive new market. In the meeting, the CEO enthusiastically presents the opportunity. No one raises concerns, and the team quickly reaches unanimous agreement to proceed despite limited market research.
questions.centerQuestion: What decision-making phenomenon is most likely occurring?

options.text: High group cohesiveness from years of working together and shared success
Directive leadership (CEO presenting preferred option first)
Insulation from external market expertise
Diverse perspectives actively sought from external advisors
Invite external market analysts to present data before decision
Assign a team member to argue against the proposal (devil's advocate)
Proceed immediately since the team has a track record of success
Have the CEO withhold preferences until after open discussion

centerOptions.text: Groupthink—the conditions and symptoms match Janis's model
Escalation of commitment to a prior project

questions.explanation: This scenario exhibits classic groupthink antecedents (high cohesiveness, directive leadership, insulation) and symptoms (illusion of invulnerability from past success, self-censorship, illusion of unanimity). The quick unanimity without dissent is particularly concerning—real deliberation involves considering risks and alternatives. Interventions should address each antecedent: bring in external experts (reduce insulation), assign a devil's advocate (legitimize dissent), and have the CEO speak last (reduce directive leadership effects). Past success does not guarantee future decisions are sound.

questions.stem: A company has invested $5 million in developing a new product over two years. Market research now shows the product will likely fail, and competitors have launched superior alternatives. Despite this evidence, the VP of product development argues that 'we've invested too much to stop now' and pushes for an additional $3 million investment.
questions.centerQuestion: What decision-making bias is driving the VP's recommendation?

options.text: Sunk cost fallacy—past irrecoverable investments should not affect future decisions but do
Self-justification—the VP needs to defend the original investment decision
Prospect theory framing—stopping feels like a sure loss, continuing offers hope
Rational cost-benefit analysis of future returns
Evaluate the additional $3M investment on its own merits, ignoring past costs
Bring in an independent evaluator not invested in the original decision
Set pre-commitment decision points ('kill criteria') for future projects
Increase the VP's personal responsibility for the project outcome

centerOptions.text: Escalation of commitment driven by sunk cost reasoning and self-justification

questions.explanation: This is classic escalation of commitment (Staw, 1976). The VP is influenced by: sunk cost fallacy (past $5M investment should not affect future decisions since it's irrecoverable), self-justification (admitting failure threatens self-image), and prospect theory framing (stopping = sure loss; continuing = possibility of recovery). Debiasing: evaluate the $3M independently ('would we invest $3M in this product if we were starting from scratch?'), bring in unbiased evaluators, and establish kill criteria in advance. Increasing personal responsibility (R4) would actually worsen escalation, not improve it.

questions.stem: A decision-making researcher is reviewing key concepts. Highlight the THREE accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Bounded rationality (Simon) proposes that decision-makers satisfice rather than optimize because of cognitive and informational limitations. (B) The Delphi method requires face-to-face interaction among experts to reach consensus. (C) Prospect theory shows that people are more sensitive to losses than to equivalent gains. (D) The Nominal Group Technique eliminates all biases in group decision-making. (E) Group polarization refers to the tendency for group discussion to push individual positions toward more extreme alternatives. (F) Escalation of commitment only occurs in individual decision-making, never in groups.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Simon's bounded rationality—cognitive limits lead to satisficing. (C) Prospect theory's loss aversion—losses are weighted more heavily than equivalent gains (approximately 2:1). (E) Group polarization—discussion amplifies pre-existing tendencies toward more extreme positions. Incorrect: (B) Delphi specifically uses anonymous, written communication—no face-to-face interaction. (D) NGT reduces but does not eliminate all biases. (F) Escalation occurs in both individual and group contexts; group settings can actually increase escalation through social commitment and conformity pressure.

questions.stem: An organizational consultant is reviewing strategies for improving decision quality. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Pre-mortem analysis—imagining the decision has failed and working backward to identify why—can improve decision quality. (B) Assigning a devil's advocate is a recommended strategy for preventing groupthink. (C) Structured decision matrices force systematic evaluation of alternatives against weighted criteria. (D) Leaders should always state their preferences at the beginning of group discussions to provide direction. (E) Decision audits that review past decisions can help organizations learn from both successes and failures. (F) Increasing group cohesiveness always improves decision quality. (G) Base rate information should be ignored in favor of case-specific vivid information.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Pre-mortem analysis (Klein) is a powerful debiasing technique that overcomes the 'champion bias.' (B) Devil's advocacy legitimizes dissent and surfaces weaknesses. (C) Decision matrices impose structure and reduce bias. (E) Decision audits promote organizational learning. Incorrect: (D) Leaders should withhold preferences to avoid anchoring and inhibiting dissent. (F) Excessive cohesiveness can lead to groupthink—the relationship is curvilinear. (G) Base rates provide critical context; ignoring them (as the representativeness heuristic leads us to do) produces poor judgments.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps of rational decision-making in the correct theoretical sequence:

options.text: Evaluate alternatives against weighted criteria
Define the problem and establish decision criteria
Implement the chosen alternative and monitor results
Generate alternative solutions
Select the alternative that maximizes expected value

questions.explanation: The rational decision-making model proceeds: (1) Define the problem and establish criteria—identify what needs to be decided and what criteria matter. (2) Generate alternatives—develop a comprehensive set of possible solutions. (3) Evaluate alternatives—systematically assess each against weighted criteria. (4) Select—choose the alternative with the highest expected value. (5) Implement and monitor—put the decision into action and track outcomes. While this model represents an ideal that bounded rationality suggests is rarely fully achieved, it provides a useful normative framework for structuring important decisions.

questions.stem: Arrange the Nominal Group Technique (NGT) steps in correct sequence:

options.text: Round-robin sharing—each member presents one idea at a time
Silent idea generation—members independently write ideas
Private voting and ranking of ideas
Group discussion to clarify and evaluate ideas
Aggregation of votes to determine final group priorities

questions.explanation: NGT (Delbecq, Van de Ven, & Gustafson, 1975) follows a structured sequence: (1) Silent generation ensures independent thinking without conformity pressure. (2) Round-robin sharing ensures every idea is heard (prevents dominance by vocal members). (3) Discussion allows clarification and evaluation, but is structured to prevent premature closure. (4) Private voting prevents social influence on preferences. (5) Vote aggregation determines priorities democratically. Each step addresses specific process losses: production blocking, evaluation apprehension, free riding, and conformity pressure.

questions.stem: Review data comparing decision quality across different group decision-making methods (quality rated 0-100 by independent experts):

questions.question: What pattern emerges regarding the relationship between decision quality and member satisfaction?

options.text: Higher quality methods always produce higher satisfaction
Structured methods improve quality but may reduce satisfaction, suggesting a quality-satisfaction tradeoff
Satisfaction and quality are perfectly correlated
Unstructured methods produce both the highest quality and satisfaction

questions.question: Why might the Delphi method show the lowest satisfaction despite high quality?

options.text: Because anonymity and lack of face-to-face interaction reduce social satisfaction
Because the method is too fast
Because it produces poor decisions
Because it requires too few rounds of input

questions.explanation: The data reveal a quality-satisfaction tradeoff: structured methods (NGT, devil's advocacy, dialectical inquiry, Delphi) produce higher quality decisions but lower satisfaction compared to unstructured discussion. This occurs because structure constrains social interaction, challenges preferred positions, and requires intellectual effort. The Delphi method shows the lowest satisfaction because anonymous written communication eliminates the social rewards of face-to-face interaction. Organizations must balance decision quality with member satisfaction to maintain long-term group effectiveness and participation willingness.

questions.stem: Examine data on escalation of commitment as a function of personal responsibility and project performance feedback:

questions.question: How does personal responsibility affect escalation of commitment?

options.text: Personal responsibility has no effect on investment decisions
High personal responsibility increases investment in failing projects, especially with ambiguous feedback
Low personal responsibility leads to greater escalation
Both groups show identical patterns

questions.question: Why is additional investment highest when feedback is ambiguous for the high-responsibility group?

options.text: Ambiguous feedback allows self-justification and selective interpretation
Ambiguous feedback is always the most informative
People prefer ambiguity in all decision contexts
The data show a random pattern

questions.explanation: Staw and Ross's research shows that personal responsibility is a key driver of escalation. When decision-makers are personally responsible for the initial decision, they invest more to justify their prior choice (self-justification theory). Ambiguous feedback enables the greatest escalation because it can be selectively interpreted to support continued investment—strong negative feedback is harder to rationalize away, while positive feedback reduces the need for additional investment. Low-responsibility decision-makers show less escalation overall because they have less psychological need to justify a decision they didn't make. This supports removing original decision-makers from de-escalation decisions.

questions.stem: Categorize each phenomenon according to whether it occurs at the individual or group level of decision-making:
questions.explanation: Individual-level: Availability heuristic, anchoring, and overconfidence are cognitive biases operating within individual minds. Group-level: Groupthink (consensus-seeking in cohesive groups), group polarization (amplification of positions through discussion), social loafing (reduced effort in groups), and process loss (coordination and motivation decrements in groups) are specifically group phenomena. Escalation occurs at both levels—individuals escalate through self-justification, and groups escalate through social commitment and shared responsibility diffusion. Understanding the level helps target appropriate interventions.

questions.stem: Categorize each strategy according to the decision-making problem it primarily addresses:

items.text: Set kill criteria in advance for projects
Use structured decision matrices with weighted criteria
Invite outside experts to challenge group assumptions
Bring in independent evaluators not tied to original decisions
Require base rate data in all probability judgments

questions.explanation: Groupthink prevention: Devil's advocacy legitimizes dissent; external experts break insulation. Cognitive bias reduction: Decision matrices impose systematic evaluation; requiring base rates counters the representativeness heuristic. Process efficiency: Pre-mortem analysis structures the critique process; NGT structures idea generation and evaluation. Escalation reduction: Pre-commitment kill criteria prevent post-hoc rationalization; independent evaluators remove self-justification pressure. Note that some strategies address multiple problems (e.g., devil's advocacy reduces both groupthink and cognitive biases), but each is categorized by its primary target.
